content: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It was constructed from 1887 to 1889 as the centerpiece of the 1889 World's Fair, celebrating the centennial of the French Revolution. Named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower, it stands 330 metres (1,083 ft) tall.

The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications made of stone, brick, tamped earth, and other materials, built along the northern borders of China. The most well-known sections were built by the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644). The Great Wall is NOT visible from the Moon with the naked eye - this is a common myth that has been debunked by astronauts. The wall is only about 15-30 feet wide.

Mount Everest is Earth's highest mountain above sea level, located in the Himalayas. Its elevation is 8,848.86 m (29,031.7 ft) as established in 2020. The China–Nepal border runs across its summit point.

Albert Einstein (14 March 1879 – 18 April 1955) was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely regarded as one of the greatest scientists. He was born in Ulm, Germany. Einstein developed the theory of relativity. His mass–energy equivalence formula E = mc² is the world's most famous equation.

Sir Isaac Newton (25 December 1642 – 20 March 1726/27) was an English mathematician, physicist, and astronomer. His book Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica, published in 1687, established classical mechanics. Newton made seminal contributions to optics and developed infinitesimal calculus.

Marie Skłodowska Curie (7 November 1867 – 4 July 1934) was a Polish-French physicist and chemist. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, the first person to win Nobel Prizes in two different sciences (Physics in 1903, Chemistry in 1911). She discovered polonium and radium.

Water is an inorganic compound with the chemical formula H₂O. At standard atmospheric pressure (sea level), water boils at exactly 100 degrees Celsius (212 degrees Fahrenheit) and freezes at 0°C (32°F). At higher altitudes, water boils at lower temperatures.

The speed of light in vacuum is exactly 299,792,458 metres per second (approximately 300,000 km/s or 186,000 miles per second). According to special relativity, this is the upper limit for the speed at which matter or energy can travel.

The adult human skeleton is made up of 206 bones. Babies are born with approximately 270-300 bones, but many fuse together during development. The skeletal system provides support, movement, protection, and blood cell production.

The Amazon River is the largest river by discharge volume of water in the world, and the second-longest river after the Nile. The Amazon is approximately 6,400 km (4,000 mi) long. The Nile is the longest river at approximately 6,650 km (4,130 mi).

The Nile is a major north-flowing river in northeastern Africa. It is the longest river in the world at about 6,650 km (4,130 mi). The Nile has two major tributaries: the White Nile and the Blue Nile.

World War II (1 September 1939 – 2 September 1945) was a global conflict involving most of the world's countries in two opposing alliances: the Allies and the Axis powers. It was the deadliest conflict in human history with 70-85 million fatalities.
The Apollo 11 mission landed humans on the Moon for the first time. Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed on July 20, 1969. Armstrong became the first person to walk on the Moon's surface.

DNA (Deoxyribonucleic acid) is a polymer forming a double helix structure. Its structure was discovered by James Watson and Francis Crick in 1953, with crucial contributions from Rosalind Franklin. DNA carries genetic instructions for all known organisms.

William Shakespeare (1564–1616) was an English playwright, poet, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language. He produced most of his known works between 1589 and 1613, with 37-39 plays attributed to him.
Vincent van Gogh (1853–1890) was a Dutch Post-Impressionist painter. He created about 2,100 artworks including around 860 oil paintings. He was largely unsuccessful commercially during his lifetime.
The Internet began as ARPANET in the late 1960s. Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 at CERN. The Web became publicly available in 1991.

Climate change refers to long-term shifts in temperatures and weather patterns. Since the 1800s, human activities have been the main driver, primarily due to burning fossil fuels. Global average temperature has increased by about 1.1°C since the pre-industrial era.
